[1/9] Teacher: Now, all of you. Sit. Listen.
[2/9] Teacher: Earth is an element of great power. Versatile and everpresent, nearly as the air.
[3/9] Teacher: Thunder provides force... Earth provides sheer power. The difference... Force chooses its own path. Power is force, directed.
[4/9] Teacher: Earth is also the earth itself. Stone, metal, trees and soil. Trees sway in the wind, but do not break. And the mountains do not crumble.
[5/9] Teacher: The Touroto, steeped in earthly magic, are nearly invincible to all but themselves. It is proof of the earth's strength.
[6/9] Teacher: The Doguns... They were masters of the earth, and fire alike, shaping caverns to their will... And now, nearly extinct. A terrible crime...
[7/9] Teacher: But we shall honor them, and move forward. We shall strike the earth and claim it to be our own.
[8/9] Teacher: The tome directs the earth's force. Take it, and utilize it to shatter the stones I summon.
[9/9] Teacher: The darkest parts of the stone are weak points. Find them, and learn the power of the earth.
[1/1] Teacher: You know the earth's power, fledgeling. There is nothing more for you here. Go.
[1/1] Teacher: Remove the dark stone using your earth magic by right click the tome.
[1/1] Teacher: Uh oh.... Time is up! Try again!
[1/10] Teacher: Hee hee, take your seats, take your seats, TAKE. YOUR. SEATS! A marvelous batch of eager students today!!
[2/10] Teacher: Almost as marvelous as the powers of Thunder! Energy! Pure, unfocused energy! Devastation, desolation, and industrialization all alike!
[3/10] Teacher: Yes, yes! Thunder is technical and versatile! Unreliable to all those who don't know how to rely upon it, to those dextrous of hand and mind!
[4/10] Teacher: But woe, woe, Thunder is reviled, reviled! Pure energy has no morality! If used for good, yes yes, ho hum, but if used for evil, oh, burn the witch! Burn, burn! Evil, they say! Pah!!
[5/10] Teacher: All magicks are unaligned with silly concepts such as morality. They are pure chaos! But thunder, the element of energy and force, it seems ever so EASY to use for evil...

[6/10] Teacher: And evil has found it, found it! CORRUPTION!! DEMONS!! Forces anathema to us, but knowledged in the ways of force, and thus, thunder! So terrible, terrible, and thunder mages feared, feared...
[7/10] Teacher: And then, then! Joyous day, the Corkians arrived with their marvelous machines, and their electromagic! Thunder controlled, thunder tamed! The wonder of it all!
[8/10] Teacher: Electromagic makes handles crank, gears spin, metal move, gives sheer stones the power to THINK, and to PLAN! A Corkian original, and a splendid, splendid development reintroduced!
[9/10] Teacher: And so, you shall see for yourselves! Electromagic at work! You will control thunder and electricity, and make the machines bend to your will today, today, this shocking day!
[10/10] Teacher: The mechanism is behind me now! Come up, come up! See the power of thunder, shackled by our whims, won't you, soldier?!
[1/2] Teacher: Whee hee hee! Thunder tamed, thunder shackled, and your magical wings unbound by such petty concepts, soldier! What a show!
[2/2] Teacher: Expand your knowledge ever further, further! Your task is complete, complete, and your next awaits!
[1/10] Teacher: Good to see a decent turnout this year for my class. Too dangerous, pah! You can take this just fine.
[2/10] Teacher: Anyways. The Fire element class. Many misunderstand just what fire stands for...but after today, you will leave with courage in your hearts.
[3/10] Teacher: Fire is, of course, related to physical fire, magma, etcetera. A burning torch is a source of fire magic, but that is not the only source of it.
[4/10] Teacher: Courage, bravery, and defensiveness are also tied to the fire element. Those stalwart and selfless, willing to sacrifice themselves for others.
[5/10] Teacher: In addition, although water is tied to healing magic, fire is tied to self-healing. Regenerative capacity, if you will. Many fire-based artifacts heal the user passively.
[6/10] Teacher: And while they are on the verge of extinction after the war in the Molten Heights, the Dogun species used to embody fire and earth magic alike. It is a shame what happened to them.
[7/10] Teacher: Unfortunately, it is also notable that corrupted creatures are often connected to fire, by nature of the corruption seeming to bring heat wherever it goes...
[8/10] Teacher: But aside from that, onto our practical test. You will all come up to me, starting with soldier, and hone your courage. I will be lobbing fireballs at the wall behind you.
[9/10] Teacher: You will need to destroy the fireballs before they hit the wall, by attacking them directly. If you are hit, it counts as a failure! Now. Let's get started, soldier.
[10/10] Teacher: Are you ready? Summon your bravery.
[1/3] Teacher: Ok Grook. I hope you're ready.
[2/3] Teacher: Lets start with 1 fireball.
[3/3] Teacher: Go!
[1/3] Teacher: Ok Grook. I hope you're ready for another test.
[2/3] Teacher: Now with... 3 fireballs!
[3/3] Teacher: Go!
[1/3] Teacher: Ok Grook. I hope you're ready for the final test!
[2/3] Teacher: With only 5 fireballs!
[3/3] Teacher: Go!
[1/2] Teacher: Well done, fledgeling Grook! Continue to sharpen your instincts. You'll be a fine hero someday, I am sure of it.
[2/2] Teacher: Dismissed, soldier. You may leave. Now, do I have any volunteers for the next round...?
[1/8] Teacher: Aah, wow! Everyone s-sure got here quick...
[2/8] Teacher: Welcome, w-welcome. The Water element class is...certainly an interesting one, I-I'd hope... Because water doesn't j-just pertain to, well, w-water...

[3/8] Teacher: It also is the element o-of knowledge, and pure magicality. Water i-is a sort of magical default, if you w-will. If it isn't focused on o-one element or another, magic ends up being water-based.
[4/8] Teacher: Learning a-about the water element and e-expanding your horizons can allow you to cast spells easier... C-control the flow of magic better, you see.
[5/8] Teacher: Most aquatic creatures are t-tied to water, though creatures that live in icy or snowy environments are, t-too...often, they are also connected to air, but not always.
[6/8] Teacher: In a-addition, many holy artifacts are enchanted with water magic... S-something about how it's a pure type of energy, I believe.

[7/8] Teacher: Lastly, healing abilities are b-bolstered by water magic. Just knowing magic well d-doesn't help, but actually having artifacts charged w-with water magic can increase healing capabilities.
[8/8] Teacher: N-now, for your test, I have...um, a...a test. Anyone who wants to try it f-first, just go up and start.
[1/2] Teacher: Good w-work there! I h-hope I wasn't too boring with all my talking... You can go now.
[2/2] Teacher: N-now, who's n-next? And...i-is it really cold in here for all of you, too? Or, is it j-just me...?
[1/12] Teacher: Arright class, the sooner we start, the sooner we finish, so everyone, take your seats! You'll be getting up soon enough anyways!
[2/12] Teacher: Movin' right along. Air! You're breathin' it, we're surrounded by it, but ain'tcha know what it's all about yet, so pay attention.
[3/12] Teacher: Air is the element of freedom! Speed, wind, and agility. If you're trained well in agility, attacks'll seem like they just phase through ya!
[4/12] Teacher: But over and above that, 'cause of air's ever-presence, it's one of the most versatile kinda of magic in existence. People use it in all sorts of ways.
[5/12] Teacher: Over in Gavel, the Bantisu Air Monks have managed to extend their sight by the wind! They use this to help guide folks who get lost in that canyon over there.
[6/12] Teacher: Many winged sorts a'creatures are tied to air, but not all of them. Some air magic users just straight-out float! Now wouldn't that be nice, eh?
[7/12] Teacher: Due to their tenuous physicality, souls and spirits are also often related to air magic. Makes ya wonder if you could just blow a ghost out the window!
[8/12] Teacher: And finally, some old, old tales tell of a woman who crossed the sea before it was calmed using air magic to fly. 's just an old legend, but an interesting one.
[9/12] Teacher: Now, onto the practical test! It's time to get those bones a-shakin'! You'll be runnin' an obstacle course I have set up, but with a twist.
[10/12] Teacher: Everyone up to the table! You'll need this feather with ya to get through. It'll help you jump higher!
[11/12] Teacher: The goal is to grab three crystal balls I put in the obstacle course. Once you find 'em, bring 'em back to me.
[12/12] Teacher: The course is behind me. Shake a leg, now!
[1/3] Teacher: Lessee here, one, two, three, yes indeedy! You got through that pretty quick!
[2/3] Teacher: Now, if you'll just hand me back that feather ya got there...
[3/3] Teacher: ...then you'll be all done! Congrats, little fledge, you've finished this class! Now get on along to your next one!
[1/1] Ghost Guide: Moving swiftly on, the next class is just across the way. Follow me!
[1/10] Teacher: Okay class, everyone take your seats, and listen up. This class is going to be interesting.
[2/10] Teacher: As you know, this class is all about magical effects, specifically those tied to various materials, and how they'll affect you!
[3/10] Teacher: This is going to be a hands-on learning experience, so those of you with weak constitutions may request to skip the demonstration if you're concerned for your health.
[4/10] Teacher: If you've read my books, you know about Quartz, and how dangerous it can be if overcharged. So, of course, we have an overcharged sample here so you can feel the signs of it.
[5/10] Teacher: It may be explosive, but it will be in a controlled manner. The worst that'll happen to you is your face will get a bit dusty, or your glasses will fall off.
[6/10] Teacher: Magical crystals, as we have to my left here, can be charged with all kinds of different effects. This is an incredibly valuable aspect for artificers.
[7/10] Teacher: Depending on the formation, they can have natural effects as well. These crystals were found in Gavel's floating islands, and...well, let's say it's difficult to keep it in its case.
[8/10] Teacher: Our last sample is of cosmic material, and if you're sickened easily, then don't examine it. Its effects are mostly unknown, but one thing's certain...
[9/10] Teacher: ...it's dangerous to be exposed for long periods. Now, each of you will go back behind me, and examine and interact with each of the three samples provided.
[10/10] Teacher: Once you've done so, then you can leave. Hands-on training is the best way to learn, after all.
[1/2] Teacher: Well done. How did that feel?
[2/2] Teacher: Personally, the void sample is the most interesting to me. You may now leave the classroom.
[1/8] Teacher: Alright everyone, take a seat but don't get comfy. You'll be getting up soon. Hope you brought your reading glasses.
[2/8] Teacher: See, I'll just be giving you a short primer, then sending you out for your practical exercise, since I have all this written down already.

[3/8] Teacher: The basis of this class is that many materials, whether you know it or not, are inherently magical in some way or another. If you want to be an artificer, you need to know how each one works.
[4/8] Teacher: Thankfully, the field of artifice is a very popular one, so there's a wealth of knowledge out there on magical materials and on how to use them effectively.
[5/8] Teacher: Heck, Wynn soldiers are cobbling together rings out of copper and old spider silk, so you know this sort of thing is easy to get into. Tough to master, though!
[6/8] Teacher: For those intimidated, you don't need much crafting knowledge for this class; you'll be reading up on everything you need to know in the back.
[7/8] Teacher: You all will be crafting a magical amulet using different items. I've got stockpiles in the back; everyone will be crafting a different kind of necklace.

[8/8] Teacher: Here's a note of what you should craft. Once you have the materials you think you need, come to the crafting table. It's enchanted, and will craft the item for you if you have what you need.
[1/2] Teacher: Mhm, that's the ticket, soldier. If you're interested in learning more, you can probably find my books at most libraries.
[2/2] Teacher: Your feathers are coming in just nicely, fledgeling. You can scoot off to your next class now.
[1/1] Ghost Guide: There's a bit of a walk to your next class. Follow me.
[1/1] Ghost Guide: These staircases were supposed to move, but... That was too much work to put together, apparently. They're a pain to navigate, aren't they?
[1/14] Teacher: Hello, students. This is your magical creatures class, and I will be your instructor.
[2/14] Teacher: Different species have different levels of innate magicality. This is often an invisible aspect of the species. You must never assume.
[3/14] Teacher: To begin with, Doguns. They are ancient creatures, artificial-seeming at first. Despite this, they are highly adept at earth and fire-based magic.
[4/14] Teacher: Able to quite literally move mountains, it is theorized that they were the ones to carve out the inside of the Molten Heights into the caves we know today.
[5/14] Teacher: Tales also tell of their utilizing demonic energy for various purposes. However, we are only able to assume their magical energy from Dwarven tales, as they are nigh-extinct.
[6/14] Teacher: Moving on. We'll touch on the societies of Trolls, Goblins, Orcs, Ogres, and Hobgoblins. Some include Gerts into this grouping, though by technicality they are separate.
[7/14] Teacher: Though many of these types of societies have mystical practices, the only known way for Orcs and such to utilize magic is through artifacts. They've little magical potential.
[8/14] Teacher: Meanwhile, Villagers are of the opposite persuasion. High magical potential, often unrealized out of laziness.
[9/14] Teacher: Humans are often thought of as more magical than Villagers, due to Fruman soldiers seeming to know some magic innately, but this is untrue.
[10/14] Teacher: Dwarves have a similar level of magicality to Humans, but like Villagers, it often goes unrealized. Their culture values physical strength more.

[11/14] Teacher: It is theorized that the reason for this is due to their distaste for the demonic energies of the Doguns. They reject their magic potential often, such that it is lessening over time.
[12/14] Teacher: Inversely, Elves have a deep connection to their magicality. Despite their reclusiveness, they are known for their open share of magical energy within their own society.
[13/14] Teacher: The outcast Elves of Efilim have shared their connection to what they refer to as 'The Light.' This connection is supposedly unfathomable, but guides them and protects them.
[14/14] Teacher: Now, we see if you were paying attention. You will come here and order the societies I have referred to in this class from least magical, to most.
[1/1] Teacher: Correct. soldier, thank you for paying attention. No one ever seems to in this class. You may go.
[1/14] Teacher: Alright, fledgeling grooks. Time to hit you all with the info you're really here for!
[2/14] Teacher: Wybels! Pronounced like ''nibble,'' they're a rather popular pet nowadays. But you all knew that, you want to know where they came from.
[3/14] Teacher: The explanation that we got was that they lived in the Ahms region, and when it split open, they eventually burrowed onto the surface of the Sky Islands.
[4/14] Teacher: But no one actually KNOWS for sure. That means they. Could. Be. ANYTHING! What could lie beneath that veneer of fluff and playful demeanor?!
[5/14] Teacher: Oh, speaking of fluff. They wooly fur never actually stops growing, ever, and neither do their hooves, their horns, or their teeth. They shed often.
[6/14] Teacher: These materials have innate magical energy to them. Stable like lodestone and reliable like quartz, but not as powerful as either. Interesting, that a fluffball has that potential!!
[7/14] Teacher: Wybel fluff is also able to be boiled, and it turns into a sticky molasses-like substance. It's used for candy, and it's very popular...but it's all POISON!!
[8/14] Teacher: It's poison, I tell you! Wybel meat is horrendously inedible! It'll give you the worst stomachache of your life! The candymakers are feeding us DEATH!

[9/14] Teacher: And the worst part is, if too much fluff gathers up in one spot, ANOTHER WYBEL APPEARS! They reproduce by budding!! Growing out of lint and dust! It's a no-win game they're makin' us play!
[10/14] Teacher: Wybels do have some good use though...they can sniff out sources of cosmic magic, like a pig sniffs out truffles. Sometimes they even try to take it home.
[11/14] Teacher: It's almost like they miss it, somehow. It's almost like they might be FROM outer space! It's ALMOST like they bring insanity-inducing things into our houses ON PURPOSE!
[12/14] Teacher: They're here to kill us all, I swear it! How else would you explain a wybel VAPORIZING a group of poachers? Ten colors of wybel, every one of them rotten evil!
[13/14] Teacher: Everyone says there's only nine, but WE know the truth! There's a tenth out there, an ultimately powerful one that wants us all gone. Pray you never see it, kids.
[14/14] Teacher: Anyways, my lesson's safe from all that. All you have to do is re-order these plush Wybel toys on the stand. You'll figure it out once you're up here.
[1/1] Teacher: Alrighty, fledgeling, good job. You're armed with the REAL truth now! Go on to your next class.
[1/2] Ghost Guide: Next class is actually rather close!
[2/2] Ghost Guide: Just follow me.
[1/18] Teacher: ...I was hoping for a smaller class size.
[2/18] Teacher: Corruption is incredibly dangerous...it'll be tough to keep so many students safe. If anyone wishes to leave, you may.
[3/18] Teacher: Now... Corruption is a force of nature of...some description. Yes, you heard me right. We don't actually know much about it.
[4/18] Teacher: Even though it's plagued the Wynn province for a thousand years, the way it behaves is so incredibly alien in nature that it's nigh-impossible to study.
[5/18] Teacher: We know it raises undead bodies... The working theory is that the more heavily injured a target is, the more susceptible they are to being corrupted.
[6/18] Teacher: And...well, you can't exactly get more injured than "dead." Hence, the growth of zombies and skeletons and all, over in Wynn.
[7/18] Teacher: It appears to spread by a complex "root" system. A scientist from Nesaak, Orikal, has studied this. The corruption spikes appear to spread it in greater concentration.
[8/18] Teacher: As for the effects on your person, most often paranoia and anger are seen. And that's about the only consistent thing with it; it affects everyone slightly differently.
[9/18] Teacher: The worst part is that practically every single thing we've touched on here is conjecture and theorycrafting! The force of corruption is terrifying.
[10/18] Teacher: The only thing we know for certain is that powerful ice-based magic can halt corruption, as seen in the Nesaak region.
[11/18] Teacher: Now, the dangerous part. Everyone, come up past my desk here. We'll examine a corrupted creature in a controlled environment.
[12/18] Teacher: We have one in captivity, and its cage is reinforced with the strongest metals we have...so dear god let it be enough.
[13/18] Teacher: Bringing it out now...be sure to back up. We don't want anyone caught in the crossfire here.
[14/18] Teacher: One thing to note about undead corrupteds...they can't be cured. You can weaken them, but that's about it. ...wait...
[15/18] Teacher: Wait, why's it spreading here? It's never done this before! E-everyone, back up, now!
[16/18] Teacher: A-as you can see, corruption is very powerful, eheheh, c-can someone go get another teacher or something?!
[17/18] Teacher: Wait, no! It's corroding the bars! Everyone, RUN! NOW! GET OUT OF HERE, CLASS DISMISSED!!!
[18/18] Teacher: GAACK! No, soldier, I said RUN! Don't fight that thing, get OUT!
[1/2] Teacher: Dear lord...that was awful. soldier, I can't believe you were able to kill that thing!
[2/2] Teacher: Class absolutely dismissed. We've got to cancel this class...it's far too dangerous for the students...
[1/10] Teacher: Welcome in, guys and gals...we're learnin' about nature magic today!
[2/10] Teacher: There's two main ways of usin' nature magic... Shamanism and Druidism. Two sides of the same coin, man.
[3/10] Teacher: Druidic practices tend to deal with healing more, and nurturing. When life's created, it gives off energy...and Druids use that energy for their magic.
[4/10] Teacher: Shamanic skills are a lot more direct, man. They take the life from other things and use that to do their stuff. It's way more varied than Druidic magic.
[5/10] Teacher: Each has its ups and downs, man. Druidism is chill and helpful...but you can really expand your mind with Shamanism, buddies.
[6/10] Teacher: Either way, it's all about equivalent exchange, y'see? You can't get somethin' from nothin', man. Either make life or take life.
[7/10] Teacher: But, it's not picky about what life you take, man! A good shaman takes from plants and animals, not people!
[8/10] Teacher: Don't be a Slykaar, kiddos. He asked for human sacrifices, but he lived in a jungle, man! Like, what the hey! He coulda done anything else!
[9/10] Teacher: Anyways. Our test today, little buds, is to practice some shamanic skills. We got a sick cow in the back, and you're gonna nurse it back to health.
[10/10] Teacher: You'll need to sacrifice some old Grooks, but it has to be just the right amount, man! The practice is through the door behind me.
[1/1] Teacher: When you think you have the right amount, activate the altar and see your results, man!
[1/1] Teacher: You may now leave.
[1/2] Teacher: Groovy work, man! You're at one with nature!
[2/2] Teacher: Your feathers are all grown out, man! Time to head out!
[1/2] Ghost Guide: That's all four classes! I hope you found them magically enriching! Now, off to the graduation hall!
[2/2] Ghost Guide: It's the room all the way at the bottom of the stairs. Hurry, don't hold up the ceremony! It won't start until everyone's there.
[1/10] Headmaster: Take a seat. The ceremony is starting.
[2/10] Headmaster: And so, your teachings, or at least their basics, have ended. Your magical feathers have started to grow!
[3/10] Headmaster: You have all been performing very well during your classes today. I've heard quite a bit of praise from the teachers being passed around.
[4/10] Headmaster: But now, for your efforts, you shall not go unrewarded. You will leave here with more than simply knowledge.
[5/10] Headmaster: Your tools have shaped your minds, subtly but inexorably. And so with that, what you leave with today, both in mind and in treasure, shall be different for each of you.
[6/10] Headmaster: Let us start with soldier. Please come up to the stage!
[7/10] Headmaster: There is a reason I've called you up first, you know. Recall what I said about old hats earlier? Don't think we didn't notice the armor, or the weapon, or the grim countenance.
[8/10] Headmaster: But no need to worry. Those who truly have the drive to become learned in the ways of magic, no matter who they are, will always find their way here, and be accepted.
[9/10] Headmaster: A shame about Seasum, but not to worry. Now, hand over your materials, and you'll receive your rewards.
[10/10] Headmaster: And there you have it. Your feathers are grown, and you can spread your magical wings! Good luck on your adventures, Wynn soldier.
[1/9] Javier: Garh, you look like a mighty fine adventurer, lad. But perhaps your pockets are a little lighter than you want, eh?
[2/9] Javier: Perhaps we be making a deal, lad, and it'll make us both rich!
[3/9] Javier: Ye see, lad, me treasure has been lost for quite some time, I kept it in a ocean village named Sarnfic, in a secret room.
[4/9] Javier: Argh, but lad. The village vanished out of nowhere! Like some kind of dark magic! I swears to ye, I tell no lies!
[5/9] Javier: So ye see, in me old age I could use a spot of me lawful gold to see me through me final years.
[6/9] Javier: Don't fret though, chuck, old Javier always kept a back up plan.
[7/9] Javier: I left me old sea farin' map in me old hideout, it'll tell ye where we can find me old gold.
[8/9] Javier: So, lad. Are ya willin' to make ye'self mighty wealthy? Good.
[9/9] Javier: Me old hideout's hidden inside that there skull at the entrance to our mighty fine establishment. Bring me that map, lad!
[1/3] Deceased Buccaneer: Halt it there, laddy! The wind has told us that yer looking for treasure map. Ah, ye'll not get it so easily.
[2/3] Deceased Buccaneer: Ye see, us spirits are as greedy as our physical selves were. 'ere's no foolin' 'round there. We want yer money, and only then will we open the paths to the map.
[3/3] Deceased Buccaneer: One full block of smashed together emeralds will satisfy our needs. Go to the front of this tomb, and flush it down the middle of that raised thing.
[1/1] Deceased Buccaneer: Good luck on that petty journey of yers. Just find the whole path, and yerself'll be just fine...
[1/6] Javier: Argh, yer talented aren't you lad! Many thanks indeed, now we can see where me treasure be buried.
[2/6] Javier: Hrmm, well, garr, blast it all!
[3/6] Javier: I canne read me own darn map, lad! What'dya do with it? Scratch off the ink with yer pennies?
[4/6] Javier: Gar, sorry lad. It be the test of time that failed old Javier, not you.
[5/6] Javier: Fear not, lad. There be an old friend of Javier's that can help decipher this old rag.
[6/6] Javier: Go to the old Mage Island, there be a man by the name of Dalben who can restore me map to its former glory. Get it done lad, and bring me treasure back!
[1/10] Dalben: What's this? A traveller? How might we assist you?
[2/10] Dalben: Ah, I see, you wish to explore the ocean depths? But for what possible reason?
[3/10] Dalben: This map... How did you acquire it? This is enchanted by our people.
[4/10] Dalben: You... You seek Sarnfic, don't you?
[5/10] Dalben: Alas, that place has history. We, the Mage Council, banished that city long ago to hide the horrific power hidden within a treasure a pirate hid there.
[6/10] Dalben: A pair of boots, made from a black material fashioned from the stone of an evil place, incredibly dark magic. But we do not believe the filthy idiotic pirate knew what he'd found.
[7/10] Dalben: I must say, we, the council regret having to lay waste an entire village over a pair of boots. There was no other way.
[8/10] Dalben: Who knows why he even kept the boots. If he had known about their power, I'm sure he would have used it for evil. But we sense no evil in you, so as such we will aid you in your quest.
[9/10] Dalben: We hope that you will use the boots for good, despite the dark intentions. We will lift the enchantment once lain upon the charts, but it will cost you.
[10/10] Dalben: Give me [5 Emerald Blocks], that should cover the cost.
[1/3] Dalben: Brilliant. That seems in order. Here you go.
[2/3] Dalben: We only hope that the boots will never fall into the hands of that pirate again, we'd much rather they fall into yours.
[3/3] Dalben: Well? What does it say? Go to that location! Find the treasure!
[1/4] Javier: Gnar, you did it lad! Ye brought back old Javiers gold! And as I promised, heres yer share of the loot.
[2/4] Javier: I threw in something extra for ye. It's an old key I salvaged a few years back, from the shipwreck of a legendary pirate.
[3/4] Javier: Who knows what it leads to? Maybe a treasure hoard, or maybe the ol' swashbuckler wanted to lead someone into a trap.
[4/4] Javier: Me bones are too old for a grand adventure like that, guess ye'll have to figure it out for yerself.
[1/9] Elphaba: Oh, a Wynnic soldier out here in the boondocks? Honestly, you're just what we need- I could use your help, if you're able?
[2/9] Elphaba: Good, thank you. Let me lock down the camp before I give you the briefing, though.
[3/9] Elphaba: My name is Elphaba. I've been working with the Gavellian army for a good few years now.
[4/9] Elphaba: I'm the commander of the Olux Outpost down ahead. It's a strategic fortress, placed to monitor the Orcish capital.
[5/9] Elphaba: It was safe for a long while, but especially in the past while the Orcs have gotten far bolder, more aggressive.
[6/9] Elphaba: They overwhelmed the outpost- we had to retreat and set up this camp to watch over the place we used to watch over them with!
[7/9] Elphaba: I need more firepower if I'm going...to get...
[8/9] Elphaba: ...oh no. See, this is what I mean! The orcs are coming!
[9/9] Elphaba: Brace yourself, soldier! Protect the camp!
[1/2] Elphaba: This is the third attack in three days! How many reinforcements have they got?!
[2/2] Elphaba: Gah! Their casters are strong, careful!
[1/1] Elphaba: Ugh, I think that was all of them... Come here now, I'll start up where we left off.
[1/5] Elphaba: Not sure I could have done that myself. I'm lucky you came around when you did, soldier.
[2/5] Elphaba: Anyway, it's clear that I'm going to need more firepower if I'm going to have a shot at reclaiming that outpost.
[3/5] Elphaba: You've certainly got the fighting chops, so I'd appreciate the aid, but we've got to come up with a plan, fast.
[4/5] Elphaba: There's an old tower near the outpost- some old storage silo. It was built taller than the fort, so we might be able to spy on them from there.
[5/5] Elphaba: It's a risk though, since it's so close by, but we have no other options. Meet me at the tower southeast of here so we can survey the situation.
[1/5] Elphaba: Soldier! I'm right behind you. You can see our outpost- and the tower I mentioned.
[2/5] Elphaba: We need to find a way in. A lot of soldiers were caught unaware during the Orcs' assault, too.
[3/5] Elphaba: If there's any survivors in there, we should make rescuing them a priority.
[4/5] Elphaba: After all, it means more manpower for us. We can't count on that being the case, though...
[5/5] Elphaba: Come on, hurry inside before one of the orcs spots us!
[1/9] Elphaba: Alright, this is a pretty clear view. Let's see what's going on in there...
[2/9] Elphaba: Wh- I'm shocked! In the middle there- they just caged the soldiers instead of killing them? That's...kind of a relief.
[3/9] Elphaba: There's definitely too many orcs in the plaza there for us to take down on our own...
[4/9] Elphaba: ...but that cage is held up by those ropes. If we can cut them, the other soldiers should be able to help!
[5/9] Elphaba: Alright, now I just need to figure out how we can both get in... There's sentries on the perimeter, so going over may not be an option...
[6/9] Elphaba: Maybe we can keep an eye out on their sentry patterns and look for an opening-

[8/9] Elphaba: Aw, not now! I knew this was a risk, no time to get out... Brace for impact!!
[9/9] Orc: Old tower fall! Junhur is best cannon shooter!!

[3/7] Elphaba: Not so much here... I'm pretty battered after that. At least one of us is in good condition...

[1/7] Marston: Ah, ahoy matey! Are ye here to get a glimpse of ol' Redbeard's sunken galleon as well?
[2/7] Marston: A fine ship it once was, aye? Accordin' to the stories, it sank in one o' the greatest sea battles in history! The cap'n sank beneath the waves, ne'er to be seen again!
[3/7] Marston: ...Say. Have ye ever wanted to go on a real treasure hunt? Ye look like someone with an eye for treasure, aye?
[4/7] Marston: Good for ye then! I bought meself a real treasure map on Pirate Cove, a fine deal if ye ask me. And, if the jack wasn't fibbing, it leads to the feared Redbeard's real treasure!
[5/7] Marston: I ventured 'round, spied some fine jacks at the island, and I collected a crew to join me on a grand, fantastic voyage!
[6/7] Marston: O' course, there always be room for another! Ye joinin'? We could use another hand.

[7/7] Marston: Aye! Let's find the booty and bring back some doubloons! Here be that map I snagged. Swim or whatever ye landlubbers do to get to Pirate Cove. It'll be the first house to the right when ye arrive.

[4/4] Karkun: Now Martim, knock the lubber out.

[3/4] Martim: Garh...I be losin' my patience. Argus arrived, let's ditch the lubber before they awake, hm? This island be hidden by magic, ain't no way they're gettin' found.
[4/4] Karkun: Arright! This key... We might be able to bring Redbeard 'imself back to life... He'll strike terror in the seas again, and we will be 'is crew!
[1/7] Marston: Can't say I expected all that... Those dogs are quick, eh?
[2/7] Marston: Fer a landlubber, ye sure are quick. When I got ta Pirate Cove, ye were already but a speck on the horizon.

[5/7] Marston: Well, lad! Methinks ye oughta go in after 'em! We may be a rowdy lot, but a mutiny's somethin' ye don't tolerate.
[6/7] Marston: They don't deserve that treasure, lad! It ain't be mine either, since I missed ye. That gold be yours fer the takin...so take it!
[7/7] Marston: Speakin' of...I ain't got much a penny ta my name, but I found this fish while ye were gone. I hear it sells for a decent haul, so here.
[1/1] Marston: It be disappointin' that I wasn't able to accompany ye. Mighta been able to thump the dogs together, eh?

[1/10] Gracen: Excuse me, traveller... I am dreadfully sorry to ask this of you, but I need your help.
[2/10] Gracen: You see, my son, Aryn. Very recently, he underwent a traditional coming-of-age ceremony from our tribe.
[3/10] Gracen: He was tasked to enter the dangerous Dernel Jungle, just south of here, and brave the wilderness for three days. He returned a true man, successful.
[4/10] Gracen: However... He also brought with him an odd purple gemstone. Our shaman saw it as a bad omen, but I was so caught up in the celebrations, I brushed it off.
[5/10] Gracen: Strange happenings began around the village. Aryn walked about at night, talking to someone, but no one else was there with him.
[6/10] Gracen: Just last sunrise, he vanished entirely. We sent out a search for him, but even our hardiest warriors could not venture deep into the jungle.
[7/10] Gracen: We returned empty-handed, having lost our newest tribesman. The village is in terrible spirits, and I feel as though I am responsible.
[8/10] Gracen: You Wynn warriors, however... Great stories are told of your exploits. Surely, you will be able to brave the jungle, yes?
[9/10] Gracen: I beg of you, please, find my son. I do not know quite where he is, but undoubtedly he has been taken quite a ways in...
[10/10] Gracen: Hm, I just now am seeing a strange trail on the ground... it matches the color of the gemstone! It may take you to him, please, follow it!
[1/4] Aryn: P-please, I beg of you spirit, let me go free! The tribesmen must be so worried-
[2/4] Aryn?: DO NOT RESIST, BOY! YOUR BODY IS MINE. I WAS TRAPPED IN THAT STONE FOR MILLENIA, AND NOW I AM FREE.
[3/4] Aryn: Aha, I hear someone coming! Surely a tribesman here to rescue me!
[4/4] Aryn?: Oh! If so, the body of this warrior will be far better suited to my needs! Grant me your power, boy! I need to thrash them first to possess them!
[1/6] Aryn: Hahah, take that, evil wraith! You'll never match the power of our tribe-
[2/6] Aryn: W-wait, you aren't part of our tribe! Who are you, why did you come here?
[3/6] Aryn: Oh... My father sent you? Well, I am very impressed, Wynn warrior. You fight with the ferocity of our own!
[4/6] Aryn: I...can't say the same for myself. That spirit completely overtook me, I still can't move right now...
[5/6] Aryn: For now, please. Take away this gemstone. It caused all this, I don't want to be near such a bad luck charm.
[6/6] Aryn: Tell the tribe that I will return on my own. I made it back once, I can do it again once I am prepared.
[1/7] Gracen: Oh my... Aryn was possessed by a spirit residing within the gemstone?
[2/7] Gracen: How shameful... Our shaman has never been wrong before, why did I disregard his warning...
[3/7] Gracen: But that is beside the point. You say you have destroyed the spirit, and it does not feel tainted any longer, so I will trust you.
[4/7] Gracen: Looking at it now, this is actually quite a valuable stone. If crushed to dust, it can be used in special charms we make.
[5/7] Gracen: Here, allow me to grind this down for you. You can keep the shards for whatever purposes you may find for them in the future.
[6/7] Gracen: Our tribe, and especially myself... We thank you for your service. We shall consider you one of our own, from this day forward.
[7/7] Gracen: In fact, if you'd like, you may even enter my house here whenever you'd like.
[1/10] Prentiss: Did ye two hear about some guy wandering around town? I've heard strange rumours about him...
[2/10] Todd: Of course I have, he's the talk of the town! I heard he only brushes his teeth once a day and that he enjoys books about gardening!
[3/10] Viola: I don't know, you guys, all these rumours seem a little far-fetched. What next? Will he suddenly turn out to be some mad scientist?
[4/10] Prentiss: Oh shush you, we're not living inside some storybook! Besides, if he *was* a mad scientist, wouldn't he be trying to take over the city like all mad scientists in stories do?
[5/10] Todd: To me that doesn't sound all that strange compared to these other things I've been hearing, anyway... Something about labs and a "hermit".
[6/10] Prentiss: I think that's a type of crab or something. Adults are right old weirdos sometimes.
[7/10] Viola: Hey, a stranger! How long have you been listening to us? Didn't your mom teach you any manners?
[8/10] Prentiss: Wait Viola, this is our chance! This stranger sure seems like they could tackle anything, even evil hermit crabs! We could just ask them to see if these rumours are true!
[9/10] Todd: Ignore my friends over there, they're always like that, but what Prentiss said was true. This might be our only chance to really know who this mystery man really is!

[10/10] Todd: It might be a good idea to look at that weird house next to those spooky ruins south-east of the city. We found this key you could try out, but if you lose it there are some spares in our base.
[1/4] Ariodo: Hello stranger! Welcome to my humble wooden abode. Comfy, isn't it? I bet you'd like a cup of this coff-
[2/4] Ariodo: Oh yes, I am the affable Ariodo, friendly neighbourhood neighbour. What do you need me for?
[3/4] Ariodo: Kidnappings? Poaching? Not brushing my teeth?! Who is this lowly person you're talking about... they don't seem like a nice fellow such as myself.
[4/4] Ariodo: Let's go, I'll take you to the exit so that I don't waste your time any longer!
[1/3] Ariodo: This is the room you came from. I call it the "Vivarium", creative name I came up with, right? It keeps my pets that aren't quite ready.
[2/3] Ariodo: Ready for what? Well that would ruin the surprise, wouldn't it? Can't have anyone finding out before the big event!
[3/3] Ariodo: Let us go now, time is precious!

[1/5] Ariodo: So you must be thinking, how have you never met a fine fellow such as myself until now? To be quite honest, you must have just been terribly unlucky, I used to travel the world, you know!

[2/5] Ariodo: Oh the places I've been were wonderful! From the depths of the jungle to the lesser depths of the jungle to even my back garden, I've done my fair share of exploring, if I do say so myself!
[3/5] Ariodo: You are the first normal person I've seen recently, Soldier. I went out recently and was met with some very rude remarks by some very rude townsfolk!

[4/5] Ariodo: The last time I visited the town it was all empty too, but I could feel people were hiding in their homes, even on such a lovely day as then. There was no one even there to hide from! Strange people.
[5/5] Ariodo: I'm just a normal guy, so why can't anyone appreciate me for once? I'm sure you do, right?
[1/2] Ariodo: Here we are, the library! I could spend years in here, but who has time for that? I could talk about books for hours too! Here's one right now.

[2/2] Ariodo: This is 'The Long-Winded and Painful Death of Sweeney S. Greenville' and I must say it is a hidden gem among books! One day it just suddenly appeared in here so I couldn't resist reading it. So it starts off with Sweeney S. Greenville...
[1/2] Ariodo: We're here now! Take the exit right in front of you, don't mind the corridor to the right, it's only decoration!

[2/2] Ariodo: Maybe you can come back some day for a tea or coffee and a long talk about books, since I noticed you were very interested in my long-winded review! Have fun out there and don't forget, I'm always here for you!
[1/1] Ariodo: The ground is shaking... I thought that was supposed to happen later! Come back friend, I can't do this alone!
[1/3] Ariodo: Help me keep this door shut, or else my surprise will be ruined!
[2/3] Ariodo: Just keep to the sides, it's safer that way.
[3/3] Ariodo: Just stay here for one more momen-
[1/8] Ariodo: Oh my, a ghost? Wait, is this just you, my trusty friend, playing a prank on me? No? Well that certainly is a problem!
[2/8] Ariodo: If you remember, we were talking about keeping the door shut when suddenly something heavy fell off a shelf hitting you square in the head!
[3/8] Ariodo: I think I heard something about fighting fire with fire, so I think I have a way to get you back! You are a bit too heavy for me, so we need to think of a workaround.
[4/8] Ariodo: During the shaking, some of my machines broke apart, but we could use these to build something capable of dropping something heavier on your head for the second time.

[5/8] Ariodo: Surely by that logic everything has to go well, you know. Now let me explain how we can do this. First, choose what part you want to use to make our machine, then choose were you want it to go and face.
[6/8] Ariodo: The [Cart] can carry the coconut from one end of the platform to another for a few tiles, while the [Fan] can push the coconut even further.
[7/8] Ariodo: The [Hammer] is able to knock the coconut over a one space gap while the [Cannon] can shoot the coconut one grid up diagonally in the direction it is facing.
[8/8] Ariodo: I think I hit my head too, so I'll need your help deciding where to place each part. You want to get the coconut across to the green tile, remember?
[1/2] Ariodo: You're back! To be quite honest, I didn't think that would work, but I'm glad it did!
[2/2] Ariodo: Quick, head through the large door and stop the cause of all that shaking!
[1/3] Ariodo: Oh no no, this is not good! If I had known that my little pet has grown so much I would have rushed you out sooner. Now it is wilted...
[2/3] Ariodo: You did what you had to, though. I am sorry to say this friend, but I think I'll stay inside a little longer. Sorry, my only friend..
[3/3] Ariodo: We'll surely meet again in the future, so don't be sad. I'll still be the one and only friendly neighbourhood neighbour when that moment comes, I promise. Goodbye now!
[1/11] Todd: You're back! You were gone for ages too, and what happened to your head? Who did the mystery man turn out to be?
[2/11] Viola: That sounds ridiculous! Who could ever belie-

[9/11] Todd: Thanks to you, we solved the case of the mystery man as well as the mystery house! For this I'd like to...

[1/1] Captain Goruca: The orcs are getting unruly... Could you come back when you're Level 64, and have some experience dealing with orcs?
[1/9] Captain Goruca: Hm. It's been long enough, we should've heard back from the diplomacy squad by now...
[2/9] Captain Goruca: Ah, hello there, Wynn soldier. You should stick around! We were just launching a counterattack against the orc citadel.
[3/9] Captain Goruca: Since you've helped with curbing the orcs elsewhere, you can join in the festivities- Oh, that's them coming over the hills!

[5/9] Soldier: I don't know, but they just decimated our golems with it. How are we supposed to deal with that chieftain without our protection?
[6/9] Soldier: Let's just get to the medical tent and go from there. The captain will need to hear about this.
[7/9] Soldier: Nonono, you don't understand- a CATAPULT?! Seriously, I can't get over this! Orc catapult! What's the world coming to?!
[8/9] Captain Goruca: ...why do you always have to embarrass me in front of the humans, you idiots...
[9/9] Captain Goruca: Obviously it seems we need some backup, soldier. Would you mind coming along to the medical tent with me?
[1/10] Captain Goruca: You lot are useless, you are! We had you sent off with thirty golems! THIRTY! And you come back with nothing to show? Do you have any idea how much that cost us?!
[2/10] Soldier: ORC CATAPULT! I'm telling you, Captain! They crushed our guard golems with huge honking boulders! What are we supposed to do against that?!
[3/10] Soldier: He's right, captain. After the golems were crushed, the orcs spilled out from the fortress. If we didn't retreat we would've been killed, with just the four of us.
[4/10] Captain Goruca: ...fine. I suppose you have a point. And that means it's a good thing we have a human here to pick up all your slack.
[5/10] Captain Goruca: Human! Let me give you the lowdown. Since you helped us reclaim the outpost up north, the orcs have gotten much more aggressive.
[6/10] Captain Goruca: There have been many attacks here at town, and weve been struggling to fend them off. Thanks to the incompetence of our troops, we haven't been able to-
[7/10] Soldier: ORC CATAPULT!! ORC CATAPULT!! Listen to the words I am telling you! ORC! CATAPULT!

[8/10] Captain Goruca: ...we haven't been able to get the orc chieftain to listen to reason and sign a new ceasefire yet. If this keeps up, we'll be overwhelmed. The brutes only seem to listen to force...

[9/10] Captain Goruca: And that's where you come in, soldier. We need you to go to the orc fortress and break through their line of defenses. Maybe if we show them we can equal their force, they'll listen, right?
[10/10] Captain Goruca: The fortress is off to the northeast, it's visible from town. Don't come back without a ceasefire- Or the chieftain's head, if peace is out of the question!
[1/2] Captain Goruca: Make whatever preparations you need to break through the orcish defenses, and then go to the orcish fortress!
[2/2] Captain Goruca: Remember, don't come back without a cease-fire...or if peace is out of the question, the chieftain's head!

[1/5] Jixy: Oh, that human who healed Ressinter. Yes, I've heard of you already. News travels fast here.
[2/5] Jixy: You have a weird face. Uh, a weird look on your face, I mean. What, not used to a more eloquent orc?
[3/5] Jixy: I'm studying languages, is why. I haven't got everything known yet, so if you feel like helping, I could use it.
[4/5] Jixy: I used to have a very smart hobbit friend who lived nearby. They've left, but I want you to check their hobbit hole to see if they left behind any language books.
[5/5] Jixy: It should be close to the blue tower on the hill. That should be easy, right?
[1/2] Jixy: You forgot already? The hobbit hole is close to the blue tower on the hill. I wanted you to look for language books in there.
[2/2] Jixy: And you gave me a weird look for being smart! Is it just because you've got a small brain?
[1/6] Jixy: Oh, good, they did leave a book behind. This even completes the collection I have. I have the first, second, fourth, fifth, and sixth volumes of this.
[2/6] Jixy: Hopefully I can learn something new here. I still don't understand what all these weird "figures of speech" are supposed to mean...
[3/6] Jixy: What does busting your hump mean? Or two shakes of a lamb tail? Well, anyway. You probably know, so me trying to guess is boring.
[4/6] Jixy: Here, then. That friend of mine wrote everything he came across down in some diaries, and he gave me them to keep, but I can't read them.
[5/6] Jixy: The pages are too flimsy- I'll rip them if I turn them. It's a good thing the book you gave me is bound with strong leather, but I still need to be careful not to ruin it...
[6/6] Jixy: Well, maybe if you read what these have written in them you can learn some things yourself.
[1/4] Jixy: We have to strip our leather into...I think your word for it was vellum, in order to make pages for our books that we won't rip so easily.
[2/4] Jixy: Anyway, we tried to learn Wynnic and low Gavellian when the villagers moved overseas- How conceited the villagers are to name their language after the country!
[3/4] Jixy: The goblins learned the language very quickly- they're good at that sort of thing. But orcish and Wynnic or low Gavellian have very different spoken structure.
[4/4] Jixy: Combine that with the war going on, and most orcs are stuck with the language only half-learned.

[1/8] Captain Goruca: Human! You're back! That certainly took you a while. I suppose all things considered I shouldn't be surprised. Those orcs are tough.
[2/8] Captain Goruca: What's this? You actually managed to get the brutes to sign a ceasefire?! I was expecting you to come back with a bloody prize, not a signature!
[3/8] Captain Goruca: After the way they so savagely attacked our outpost and the way they've rebuffed our diplomacy squads, I wasn't expecting this.
[4/8] Captain Goruca: Still, this is good! The terms are a bit more airtight than I'd prefer, but I suppose as long as they're out of our hair anything will do.
[5/8] Captain Goruca: Hm? The orcs were talking about the decay up north? Not sure how that matters. It isn't like anyone knows what's causing it.
[6/8] Captain Goruca: I mean, have you heard the rumors flying from Lexdale? Saying witches are cursing the land, hah! Well, thats besides the point.
[7/8] Captain Goruca: Here- your reward. I'd intended on giving you the mask so you could try and sneak in like one of them, but I...well, I forgot about it til you'd already left.
[8/8] Captain Goruca: But I DID magically fortify it into a potent piece of gear instead! So it ought to serve you well. We thank you for your service, human!
[1/1] Captain Goruca: You know, that one guy was going off about that orc catapult or whatever the entire time you were gone. Hes shut up now, but criminy!
[1/5] Yavlis: Oh, hello there! I had hoped not to bother you, adventurer, but this is urgent.
[2/5] Yavlis: You see, the king is very...erm, distracted, and you are just the kind of willing, able-bodied person I need.
[3/5] Yavlis: You see, the king's son has gone missing, and with him worrying so much, the problems of the city have festered unsolved.
[4/5] Yavlis: We believe he was kidnapped by the splinter cell mercenaries in the jungle... Unfortunate, too. They used to be quite honourable.
[5/5] Yavlis: Well, anyway, they're usually spotted outside the run-down farm outside of town. Go there and see what they want in return for the young prince.
[1/7] Mercenary Leader: Excuse me?! What are you doing here, how did you find our secret hideout?
[2/7] Mercenary Leader: Oh, you're here for the boy? A mighty fine steal, that one! The boy won't be leaving this establishment for free. I'll need some nice loot for him.
[3/7] Mercenary Leader: Ah, but what to have you fetch... oh, haha! This would be a perfect opportunity to obtain that... Alright, ears open!
[4/7] Mercenary Leader: There's a certain talisman that we aren't able to get to in the temple not far from here. It has special abilities that allow my men to be strengthened, see.
[5/7] Mercenary Leader: The guardians there pack quite the punch, and there's some nasty mechanism in the way that we just can't crack.
[6/7] Mercenary Leader: The temple is found just across the waterway, in a crevice in the mountain. It used to be blocked until those WynnExcavation fellows tried digging there.
[7/7] Mercenary Leader: You get that talisman in my hands, and the king's boy is yours. Now off you pip! I'm a very busy man.
[1/3] Mercenary Leader: You've gotten the talisman! I can't believe you actually got through that puzzle!
[2/3] Mercenary Leader: At this point I would usually keep the kid and throw you out of here, but since you've done what I've asked in such a timely fashion, he's all yours.
[3/3] Mercenary Leader: When you get back to whoever asked you to do this, tell him to leave my men and I alone! We guildsmen lay down our lives every day, we don't need any more hostile onlookers!

[3/4] Prince of Troms: It's not like my father ever listened to me when I told him. He wouldn't even let me out of the castle.

[3/5] Yavlis: Alright then, if that's the path the king's son chooses to walk, then there's nothing we can do.

[5/5] Yavlis: Such a shame that old guild has stooped to such a level. Well, we must thank you for your help. You can have the emerald ransom we had intended to pay.
[1/1] Ferndor: Have you seen boots called Abysso Galoshes on your journey? A pirate stole them from us years ago! I could reward you if you could bring me the [Abysso Galoshes] and help us!
[1/8] Ferndor: I see you have the infamous galoshes with you. But do you know even half of the story of them?
[2/8] Ferndor: The boots were once owned by my ancestors, who decided to lock it away in this manor years ago.
[3/8] Ferndor: Nobody knows why they decided to hide the boots just after they got into my family's hands. I was told they were acquired from a strange man with pale grey skin.
[4/8] Ferndor: We think they hid the boots in some kind of basement in the manor. You can get to it by following the river to the waterfall, but you will need some kind of code to open it...

[5/8] Ferndor: I remember Grandon saying that he found a book which is apparently a diary from one of my ancestors. Ever since that filthy pirate raided our home and stole our treasures, weird things have been happening.
[6/8] Ferndor: Grandon should already have finished reading it. If I allow you to enter my home, would you talk to him?
[7/8] Ferndor: There are strange things going on in this mansion and I hope that book reveals everything we need to know...
[8/8] Ferndor: I almost forgot to give you your boots back, I am not sure if I want to have them near me. Remember, it is imperative you find the 4 digit code to the basement.
