[1/1] Jofash Resident: Hey-o, human! What can I do for ya?
[1/1] Jofash Resident: What can I do for you?
[1/3] Jofash Resident: Oh, you know me, pal, just doin' the rounds.
[2/3] Jofash Resident: Waterin' the pots, starin' at the water, potterin' the sta-
[3/3] Jofash Resident: ...wait, scratch that last one.
[1/99] Jofash Resident: You know what, I'm glad you asked.
[2/99] Jofash Resident: Lots of people these days are going crazy for that 'all-natural, multiple grains, bred ethically' garbage.
[3/99] Jofash Resident: Really, I wish I could see those nutters sit down and take a good bite of some raw, authentic Rye, or a hearty whole-wheat.
[4/99] Jofash Resident: That's the stuff that puts hairs on your chest, my pappy used to say. Good, strong, proper bread from out in the fields.
[5/99] Jofash Resident: We used to be farmers, you know. Out near Maltic. WHEW! Glad I moved here though! Not so many places serve better rum than good ol' Jofash!
[6/99] Jofash Resident: Back to the point at hand, though, bread. Man oh man I feel like I could go on forever about this.
[7/99] Jofash Resident: You know what people always miss when discussing bread, the CONSISTENCY! The consistency is consistently the most im-
[8/99] Jofash Resident: Oh, haha, 'consistently,' didn't even mean to do that. Heheh...
[9/99] Jofash Resident: Ah, there you are! The ol' train of thought gets derailed sometimes, you see.
[10/99] Jofash Resident: But I can tell that you're a real enthusiast for bread!
[11/99] Jofash Resident: Back to the topic at hand! Consistency! The consistency is consistently the most important part of any good loaf.
[12/99] Jofash Resident: Overusin' so-called 'refined' grains is a sure and done way to get runny slop that's not fit for the pigs.
[13/99] Jofash Resident: Come to think, you shouldn't feed pig refined grains anyway. It's hard on their digestion.
[14/99] Jofash Resident: Of course! Digestion. A topic I'll get to later!
[15/99] Jofash Resident: Anyway, whole grains are where the money's at! I'd swear it on these plants.
[16/99] Jofash Resident: What you want is a thick-crusted, chewy loaf that you can savor! Not some frail morsel that collapses under its own weight. Why, the things I've seen...
[17/99] Jofash Resident: In particular, have you seen some of the scraps sold at Ahmsord? Ridiculous!
[18/99] Jofash Resident: I'll let you in on a little secret. The Sky's Kitchen's great and all, but what passes for bread there is intolerable. No substance at all!

[19/99] Jofash Resident: What you'll want to do is get it straight from the fields, right from the soil! Well, not literally, but from the countryside! Leave breadmakin' to those who've been workin' with grain before they could even walk on two legs!
[20/99] Jofash Resident: Heck, I bet even I could do a better job than those snobby sauciers.
[21/99] Jofash Resident: Right. Digestion. The fiber in whole-grain bread is a real lifesaver.
[22/99] Jofash Resident: Did you know that whole-grain bread has four times the fiber of white bread? Now you do!
[23/99] Jofash Resident: Helps keep you full and fit. Want to avoid lookin' like a loaf of white bread yourself? Fiber's your man.
[24/99] Jofash Resident: Nothin' beats a rich, fresh-ground fresh-baked loaf with a slab of flat-iron steak. Red meat and fiber makes a real man, as my pappy once said.
[25/99] Jofash Resident: Oh, how time flies. Where was I? Right, white bread.
[26/99] Jofash Resident: That stuff's poison, I tell you! Not a lick of nutritional value!
[27/99] Jofash Resident: It's more milk and sugar than bread! Hardly somethin' you'd want to eat, never mind something for which you'd pay extra!
[28/99] Jofash Resident: Those hawkers can pretend that it's an upper-crust good all they want, but we all know it's just a waste of dough.
[29/99] Jofash Resident: Heheh, I did it again! Sorry, sorry, I'll get the train back on track. Heh...
[30/99] Jofash Resident: Blendin' grains? Why jumble the flavors and textures? Just make two loaves of bread instead of one! Or several, if we're talkin' about more than two types of grain.
[31/99] Jofash Resident: Say, that reminds me! Bread's probably the most versatile food. You can make it from just about any type of grain.
[32/99] Jofash Resident: But just because you can doesn't mean that you should. Who could stomach somethin' like 'Oatmeal-Bran Fusion Delight'? WHO WOULD EVEN MAKE BREAD OUT OF OATS?!

[33/99] Jofash Resident: Just a waste of food, in my opinion. Sure, it may be the hottest new culinary sensation now, but it'll die out like any other idiotic fad in just days. I'm positive that nobody's eatin' it for the taste, that's for sure. Like 'Seven Colors of the Grainbow,' or 'Hearty Hemp-tastic,' or...
[34/99] Jofash Resident: ...and don't get me started on 'Pain au Cinfras'! But really, Oatmeal-Bran Fusion Delight is among the worst. Oh! That reminds me about a better use for oats.
[35/99] Jofash Resident: If you want to avoid bein' three sheets to the wind after a busy night of Jofash Rum, then eat a hearty bowl of oatmeal.
[36/99] Jofash Resident: Sounds crazy, I know. But it actually works. Take it from me; I've tried it!
[37/99] Jofash Resident: While anythin' made of grain helps, oats are particularly good at this.
[38/99] Jofash Resident: And I'd bet my bread that you'd rather eat oatmeal than Oatmeal-Bran Fusion Delight, whatever that's supposed to be.
[39/99] Jofash Resident: Though it seems like you just can't get a good loaf of bread nearby. Sure, there's sailin' biscuits, but that hardly qualifies!
[40/99] Jofash Resident: I can't stomach the fancy stuff, so I just make my own. Not only is it cheaper, but it also tastes much better.
[41/99] Jofash Resident: It isn't too difficult. Besides the obvious, you'll just need some salt and yeast. Grab something to write with, y'hear? Take some notes!
[42/99] Jofash Resident: Ready? Right, let's get started! The less ingredients you use, the closer you'll get to makin' a real loaf! Not the wannabe poundcakes eaten by wannabe spendthrifts.
[43/99] Jofash Resident: There's a common misconception that you need sugar for yeast to start risin'. Not true!
[44/99] Jofash Resident: Give it some time, and bread without sugar will rise just as well. If you want somethin' good, you need to put in the time and effort for it!
[45/99] Jofash Resident: Get it right, and you'll have the perfect taste and texture for nothin' more than a few hours of your time!
[46/99] Jofash Resident: Let me make it clear: you don't want sugar in your bread. It'll do a number on its taste and your teeth.
[47/99] Jofash Resident: I'll cover the taste first. The sugar fights with the raw, savory flavors of an otherwise respectable loaf of bread.
[48/99] Jofash Resident: It also fights with your teeth. Bread's quite sticky as it is, and the sugar doesn't do it any favors.
[49/99] Jofash Resident: Why, I can still remember the time that I got a cavity. Cried my eyes out, I did.
[50/99] Jofash Resident: Eventually, my pappy had enough, and he went for the ol' string-on-a-doorknob trick. He got me good there, though it took him a few tries.
[51/99] Jofash Resident: Ah, it seems like I got distracted. Back to the topic at hand.
[52/99] Jofash Resident: You aren't goin' to get quite as much of an effect on your digestion than coarse-ground whole-grain bread. It keeps most of the fiber intact, after all.
[53/99] Jofash Resident: You know how fruit juice contains next to no fiber because none of it goes into the juice? It's the same deal with white bread.

[54/99] Jofash Resident: Fruit juice was banned in my household. As my pappy liked to say, a real man only drinks hard spirits and the sweat runnin' down his face! Though I wasn't allowed to have the former, not yet at least! Heheh! So I drank milk instead.
[55/99] Jofash Resident: Say, if you haven't done so already, try bread dipped in milk! Go on! There's nothin' quite like it. Don't accidentally drop the bread into the milk, of course.
[56/99] Jofash Resident: You'll end up with a bloated mess with the consistency of a sponge. And you should know by now that consistency is everythin'!
[57/99] Jofash Resident: While we're on the subject of milk, do you know how some folks can't drink it? Oh, yes, they can try, but sooner or later their belly will protest.
[58/99] Jofash Resident: It's the same deal with bread! Stick with whole-grain, nothin' added. That way, you don't have to worry about surprise milk appearances and whatnot.

[59/99] Jofash Resident: You got that? Let me know when you're ready for more. Say, you know what? I oughta talk a bit slower to help you digest what I'm sayin'. Oh! 'Digest'! I did it again! Heheh...
[60/99] Jofash Resident: Right, then, somethin' that really peeves me is people who use bakin' powder. What's wrong with some good ol' yeast?
[61/99] Jofash Resident: Too little of it, and it'll go plum flat in the oven. Just a little too much of it, and your bread's goin' to be as bitter as wormwood!
[62/99] Jofash Resident: The only way to get a size that's just right is the long way! Wait until the yeast works its magic, and bake it right as it reaches a good size.
[63/99] Jofash Resident: There's also nothin' quite like the smell of yeast as it causes the dough to rise! Works up quite the appetite, it does.
[64/99] Jofash Resident: Some people put the cart before the horse and think that yeast works like bakin' powder. Try that, and you'll end up with some scorchin'-hot bricks in your oven.
[65/99] Jofash Resident: No, you have to do it right, and doin' it right means leavin' some of the work to the yeast.
[66/99] Jofash Resident: Unless you like flat breads. I can't see why anyone would, though. Bread's supposed to be puffy and chewy, not some dough jerky!
[67/99] Jofash Resident: Though that may not be the case for some other pastries. For one, I've never once heard of a pie with a chewy crust.
[68/99] Jofash Resident: Really, the beauty in bread lies with its simplicity! No complicated steps, no chances for the dough to rebel. Certainly not as fickle as somethin' like a cream puff.

[69/99] Jofash Resident: If you treat the dough with respect, the bread will respect you in turn. It's simple stuff, really! No finnickin' around with stiff peaks, or needin' half a dozen bowls to mix in, or getting a flaky dough just right, or...
[70/99] Jofash Resident: ...and not to mention that just about everythin' needs butter in some shape or form! Really, what's with it? It's not like the stuff grows on trees!
[71/99] Jofash Resident: Makin' the pastry shiny. Makin' it taste rich. Makin' the dough thick. There's no end to it! Bread's so much simpler to handle.
[72/99] Jofash Resident: Though some people insist on putin' butter in the bread. Not just on it, but in it! There's more butter than bread at that point!
[73/99] Jofash Resident: I don't have anythin' against butter itself, mind you. It's great on toast! Just I think that it oughta stay on the toast rather than in it.

[74/99] Jofash Resident: Not to mention there's a time, place, and occasion for it. If you put butter on everythin, you're goin' to get sick of it real quickly. Eat it in moderation! Your tongue and your emerald pouch will thank you.
[75/99] Jofash Resident: Of course, there's always margarine, but why settle for somethin' inferior? You shouldn't settle for anythin' less than the quality you'd expect from your bread!
[76/99] Jofash Resident: Though, now that I look at it, bread does get a reputation for bein' a breakfast food. That's ridiculous! It's got a place in every meal of the day!
[77/99] Jofash Resident: Sandwiches? They've got bread in 'em. Casseroles? Any respectable one has it as a shell. Bread sticks? It's in the name, for cryin' out loud!

[78/99] Jofash Resident: Done right, and it's also great as a side. I already mentioned havin' a fresh-ground fresh-baked loaf of hole grain with a slab of flat-iron steak, but really, a well-sliced loaf and some dippin butter can transform a family dinner into a banquet!
[79/99] Jofash Resident: They're almost as versatile as potatoes! Actually, even more so, I'd say!
[80/99] Jofash Resident: As my pappy liked to say, a real man's got to earn his daily bread through his own toilin'. As you can see, I've taken his advice to heart!
[81/99] Jofash Resident: ...I feel that I'm missin' somethin' important that I wanted to discuss. Hang on for a bit, would you?
[82/99] Jofash Resident: Ah, of course! I can't believe that I forgot! I wanted to cover some thoughts about bread consistency.
[83/99] Jofash Resident: Namely, the two extremes: too chewy and not chewy enough. I already spoke on hardly chewy bread plenty, but there's such a thing as too much of a good thing.
[84/99] Jofash Resident: And in this case, bread chewiness is the good thing. You don't want your bread to be too chewy, got it?
[85/99] Jofash Resident: Too chewy's a step right towards bread that's outright rubbery. Your teeth'll bounce right off it!
[86/99] Jofash Resident: Sure, too much give in the dough's awkward and sets you up for bitin' your own tongue, but too firm of a loaf can lead to much of the same.
[87/99] Jofash Resident: They always say never to bite off more than you can chew, but you oughta be careful not to bite off any less than that, either!
[88/99] Jofash Resident: No, just right and chewy's what you want. Don't settle for anything more or less!
[89/99] Jofash Resident: Hmm, come to think. You seem really interested in discussin' bread with me!
[90/99] Jofash Resident: Lean in for a second, would you? I've got somethin' important to say.
[91/99] Jofash Resident: Listening? Right! Ah, sorry, I didn't mean to shout in your ear.
[92/99] Jofash Resident: You're just about the only person that I've been able to have an honest conversation about bread with.

[93/99] Jofash Resident: Usually, bread gets brushed off as some kind of dull fodder. Dismissed as too borin' and plain, I tell you! That's what leads to unnecessary excess as people try to make it into something that it's not.
[94/99] Jofash Resident: But us? We're different, we're visionaries, and we know the truth about what really makes a good loaf!
[95/99] Jofash Resident: Tell em off, I say! They can't follow the thoughts of bread enthusiasts like you and I otherwise!
[96/99] Jofash Resident: Ah! Right, I never did get to answerin' your question. About my favorite type of bread, that is...
[97/99] Jofash Resident: Plain ol' coarse-ground wheat.
[98/99] Jofash Resident: Sure, it may be simple, but if you were payin' any attention at all, you'd know for sure why that's everythin' that I'm lookin' for.
[99/99] Jofash Resident: And that just about sums up the basics! Let me know if you want to hear anythin' more.

[1/11] Scientist Ynnos: *Ahem* Welcome, everyone.
[2/11] Scientist Ynnos: I am Ynnos, one of the leading scientists in Gavel. Youre here because.. Well you read the help wanted sign.
[3/11] Scientist Ynnos: Allow me to explain the situation were in. Its a series of unfortunate events. I study the amazing properties of crystals and other geodes.
[4/11] Scientist Ynnos: I was funded by a private organisation, however that seems to have stopped. So.. We had to make cuts in the budget.
[5/11] Scientist Ynnos: One of those, was using cheaper rope. While moving the crystal across Ahmsord, well, it snapped. The crystal fell.
[6/11] Scientist Ynnos: I can not stress the value of that crystal. It had many unique properties that are allowing me to understand why the sky islands float the way they do.
[7/11] Scientist Ynnos: They hold the very key to restoring this land to being whole once more... But its gone.
[8/11] Scientist Ynnos: Fortunately, I detected an impact. Its hit something down in the void. Were not sure what, however or how deep.
[9/11] Scientist Ynnos: Your mission will be to retrieve the crystal in a specially designed ship to withstand the void. We barely scraped it out of the budget, so try to bring it back in one piece.
[10/11] Scientist Ynnos: If you think you are not up for the challenge, leave now...
[11/11] Scientist Ynnos: When you think you are ready, exit the room behind me and meet me at the dock as soon as possible.

[1/1] Rhay: Well? What are you waiting for- come on, let's get going to Corkus!
[1/12] Rhay: Well, there it is! The Canyon Colossus itself. The source of all of our problems here at Kandon-Beda.
[2/12] Rhay: So! How much do you already know? I know we dragged you into this without telling you much, so... I can fill you in on the details.
[3/12] Rhay: Oh, he did? Right, that makes sense. Well, you're right in that it's the source of the earthquakes, but there's more to it than that.
[4/12] Rhay: You've seen the Sky Islands, right? Heard of the Fracturing. From what we can tell, what happened to that region a thousand years ago is happening again, here and now.
[5/12] Rhay: Yes, exactly. It's been malfunctioning for a long time now, and it's starting to tear the canyon apart. That's where we come in.
[3/12] Rhay: Well... To start with, it's an ancient thing. It was built long before even the doguns can remember, and they've lived in this region for thousands of years.
[4/12] Rhay: According to Ineos, the doguns used to be responsible for keeping it calm, but ever since the dwarves came in and started their war, that knowledge has been lost to time.
[5/12] Rhay: Which is... a problem! The Colossus has been malfunctioning for hundreds of years, and it's reaching its breaking point. If we don't stop it, it'll tear the canyon apart.
[3/12] Rhay: Oh? So you've traveled the canyon, then. Yeah, then you've seen how the canyon twists and changes.
[4/12] Rhay: It destroys peoples' homes, it traps them deep within the maze-like valleys... And, more recently, it has been tearing a hole into the void.

[5/12] Rhay: This thing is ancient, and we don't know how it works. The best we can do is try and keep it from reaching its breaking point, and prevent the canyon from meeting the same fate as the Sky Islands.
[6/12] Rhay: So, Gavel's government contacted us in Corkus some time ago, requesting our help to deal with this threat.
[7/12] Rhay: Our council agreed, and we got to work designing a machine that could replicate the dogun magic that pacified the Colossus long ago.
[8/12] Rhay: We've had Ineos' help on that front. He and I have been working here in Kandon-Beda to ensure things are running smoothly. Which... evidently, they are not.
[9/12] Rhay: ... We'll be fine! We're going to meet up with my husband at Corkus, and he'll know what to do. He always does.

[10/12] Rhay: Our people working there will be able to get us the parts we need to repair the device. This... this isn't the first time it's exploded. I had hoped that this time we would have gotten it stable, but...
[11/12] Rhay: But, hey! We have it under control. We're always able to repair it quickly enough to keep it running while the Colossus is active.

[10/12] Rhay: Oh! Yeah. He's the one responsible for the design and production of this device. He's got a talent for designing these sorts of things, without him... well, we'd be in a much worse situation than we are now.
[11/12] Rhay: I'll be glad to see him again. It's been a while since I last had to travel to Corkus, and... Well, I'm confident he'll know what to do here. He always does.
[12/12] Rhay: ... Right! Hey, it looks like we're almost there. We'll be able to get this all sorted out, and we'll be back to Kandon-Beda in no time.
[1/15] Rhay: Alright, let's just head on in. My husband should be around here somewhere...

[3/3] Aledar: Oh no, I think something is coming... soldier! Fight it off, I don't think I can defend myself right now!
[1/12] Aledar: Huff... Not feeling totally better, but... At least I can still defend myself.
[2/12] Aledar: My stomach is empty, I can't even vomit... Why do I still feel so dizzy? Maybe a potion will help...
[3/12] Aledar: Hm. No, not that one...
[4/12] Aledar: Urgh, pfft! My vomit tasted better than that coming up...
[5/12] Aledar: Hah...that's the ticket. Which potion was this anyways... ...hair loss treatment? Why did THAT work?
[6/12] Aledar: Though, you saw what happened to that beast I attacked? Follow me.
[7/12] Aledar: This, from what I recall of the mission statements, is referred to as a Void Hole. It's a sort of portal.
[8/12] Aledar: They connect to each other in odd ways, but we saw the beast come out of that one when I knocked it in, so...
[9/12] Aledar: Watch. I'll come out the other side.
[10/12] Aledar: Alright, good! It does connect up consistently, at least. You try now.
[11/12] Aledar: I bring this up because if we're seeing one, we'll be seeing more soon. You'll need to adjust yourself to the sight of them.
[12/12] Aledar: You lead again, please.
[1/3] Aledar: We grossly underestimated the difficulties we would have here. And, by that, I mean myself, Elphie, and Lucio did...
[2/3] Aledar: We were each unprepared and cocky. If it weren't for you, I'd be dead now, for what it's worth.
[3/3] Aledar: I wasn't certain at first about you coming along, but you've more than shown you were the right one for the job.
[1/11] Aledar: ...I had to figure this map was outdated. This wall of spikes isn't listed on it, and the path goes through here!
[2/11] Aledar: I'll have to assume they're new...and if they're new, I might be able to bash through them.
[3/11] Aledar: soldier, try throwing a spell at the same time! Let's crack through these things!
[5/11] Aledar: ...aagh... I... H-how are these so resilient...?
[6/11] Aledar: I'm an idiot... I nearly killed myself trying that. I nearly ruined the mission...
[7/11] Aledar: I'm sorry, but you'll have to go without me. I can't move another step for now.
[8/11] Aledar: There's a lot of void holes around here, remember my warning... You can probably get past these spikes with one.
[9/11] Aledar: If I'd been thinking I would have suggested it earlier... Once you're past, we'll...uh. We'll do something.
[10/11] Aledar: Just...be careful where you go. The void holes could lead anywhere. They might lead you someplace very, very dangerous, too dangerous even for you. I pray they won't...
[11/11] Aledar: There's a void hole right there to try out first. Get going, now. You have to do this.
[1/5] Aledar: ...wait, soldier? You got to the other side then...? Good...
[2/5] Aledar: I don't know what you did, but whatever it was, it's made cracks in the spikes that I can see from this side.
[3/5] Aledar: I've got some of my energy back...let's try spellcasting again. If we do it at the same time, we might make some headway.
[4/5] Aledar: I won't crack my skull open on the spikes again though. Promise.
[5/5] Aledar: You lead. I'll cast my spell as soon as I hear yours.
[1/20] Aledar: Thank god it worked... That's our destination there, the Eldritch Outlook.
[2/20] Aledar: Now comes the hardest part... Come along. I'll need you there for it.
[3/20] Aledar: That blade there...it's made for sacrifice. See how that gate is shut?
[4/20] Aledar: In order to open the doors to the Outlook, we need to sacrifice a powerful soul.
[5/20] Aledar: If you haven't gotten it already, the plan was to sacrifice our fourth. It's why I was hesitant about having you come along, though it was perfect.
[6/20] Aledar: Think about it. A soldier with no relations, no loved ones, and no way to deny their fate. But...
[7/20] Aledar: I've been mulling it over since we got to the town... You'll sacrifice me instead. I won't take no for an answer.
[8/20] Aledar: I mean...look at the state I'm in, soldier! I'm on death's door already, and you've proven yourself far stronger than I am even at my best.
[9/20] Aledar: Here. You can take everything I had on me. My emeralds, and the key to the dungeon. I certainly won't be able to use them anymore.
[10/20] Aledar: Upon the top of the tower is... Well, something. We don't know for certain what it is, but it will prevent you from passing through.
[11/20] Aledar: You'll have to kill it to break the barrier. But...find other soldiers who can help you. It will be impossible to defeat alone.
[12/20] Aledar: ...no more putting it off, then. I'm bleeding out.
[13/20] Aledar: Grab the blade, soldier.
[14/20] Aledar: Now...strike me down. My soul will unlock the gate...
[15/20] Aledar:  Agh... Don't worry...a-about me...
[16/20] Aledar: You...can do this. I know y-you can.
[17/20] Aledar: Gah... D-Destroy it...
[18/20] Aledar: The monster w-watching us...
[19/20] Aledar: AAAAGH!!
1/1theeye
[1/5] Lutho Citizen: Wait... It can't be. Look me in the eyes. You are human, like me.
[2/5] Lutho Citizen: Well, maybe not anymore. Look around you. These people are barely alive.
[3/5] Lutho Citizen: I have kept my eyes because I chose to keep them.
[4/5] Lutho Citizen: Now you are here you will have to make that same decision. Just remember this:
[5/5] Lutho Citizen: No Matter what, you MUST KEEP GOING.
[1/5] Lutho Citizen: Ahh.. A newcomer! Welcome, welcome!
[2/5] Lutho Citizen: Don't worry, you are safe here. The Obelisk protects.
[3/5] Lutho Citizen: It arrived here.. Uhm. Hm. You know, I can't remember when.
[4/5] Lutho Citizen: It's been here a while.
[5/5] Lutho Citizen: Anyway, feel free to look around.
[1/4] Lutho Citizen: I can't see why anyone would choose to stay there.
[2/4] Lutho Citizen: I don't blame you for being here.
[3/4] Lutho Citizen: We all chose this, in the end. There wasn't much of an alternative.
[4/4] Lutho Citizen: Thank Grook that the obelisk is here to help us.
[1/4] Lutho Citizen: It's been quite some time since a new face has shown up here.
[2/4] Lutho Citizen: Don't be fooled, everything you see is very real.
[3/4] Lutho Citizen: At least, in a sense that matters. The Obelisk protects us.
[4/4] Lutho Citizen: You should go and take a closer look at it.
Hello soldier.
I am you.
You are me.
We are one.
Not here, though.
The Obelisk offers us different paths
It offers to protect me, while leaving you in reality.
If you want to return as one, you must heed my words.
I may not be able to speak in the physical realm...
But your actions... Your deeds... They shape me, hurt me, heal me.
Choose our path wisely.
Something is holding us back.
You must keep going.
We must keep going.
Are you sure we want to face reality?
The only one holding us back is us.
[1/1] Lutho Guard: If you really want to leave, no one is stopping you. Except maybe yourself.
[1/5] Lutho Citizen: You- you chose to come back. I saw your eyes disappear, briefly.
[2/5] Lutho Citizen: As you can see... Everyone in this town chose to stay there.
[3/5] Lutho Citizen: It started as just one or two.. But over the years more and more people chose to stay.
[4/5] Lutho Citizen: Now the shells are kept functioning by some blessing or curse of the obelisk.
[5/5] Lutho Citizen: Im the last one to choose reality.. Although I wonder if it might just be easier to...

???: You wonder. What do we speak of? To what end?
???: You panic. We know you. How? We can provide no answer.

[1/4] Bak'al: We destroy Ragni today. The great fortress will fall.
[2/4] Bak'al: I will find their protector, Bob. You each will engage the guards and city dwellers. 10 citizens.
[3/4] Bak'al: If each of you kills 10 citizens, then the city will run empty. So, you shall make it run empty.
[4/4] Bak'al: Go!
???: You anger. Viewing needless destruction. To what end?
???: You distrust. We are dark. Are we? You believe it so.

[1/4] Amadel: Hey, little miss. Don't go spacing out on me like that.
[2/4] Amadel: Now that you're acquainted with the new laws we'll want to introduce, I've got a job for you to do.
[3/4] Amadel: The current mayor is human. He'll inevitably veto the laws. The deputy on the other hand, is a villager, and on our side. See what I'm getting at.
[4/4] Amadel: Another employee has already been sent out to get things started. He'll know what you need to do, so meet up with him, would you?
[1/2] Citizen: Oh, yeah I saw the mayor not too long ago.
[2/2] Citizen: He was headed towards the bank. Why're you wondering, miss Villager?

[2/4] Employee: So our mission is to assassinate the mayor. Amadel told you about the laws. We have a puppet in the running who'll rubberstamp them.
[3/4] Employee: I've got the trap set up inside the bank. It was entirely too tricky, but it worked out. Your job is to trigger the trap.
[4/4] Employee: Climb up the tree behind me and look through the window, you should be able to see it from there.
[1/1] Bodyguard: No one enters when the mayor is doing his errands, sorry. You'll have to wait for your transaction.
[1/3] Employee: Can you see the mayor? I had to stay totally out of sight while setting this all up, so...

[3/3] Employee: You can absolutely not be spotted. The way up to the ceiling is on the opposite side of the bank. Just keep on walking past the guards, play it cool.
[1/1] Employee: Quickly, back to the camp. Before we're noticed.
[1/4] Amadel: Aha, you two are back.
[2/4] Amadel: Is everything taken care of?
[3/4] Employee: Yes sir, everything went smoothly, playerName did a great thing for the company.

???: You misinterpret. What you see... Is it true? How?
???: The answer... It will not bring you the end.
???: You see. Yet you do not understand. So, may we offer an end?

[5/5] Bak'al: Nesaak is behind me. Move.

[4/5] Bak'al: You will release him from this cave. Whether you die afterwards is irrelevant. He will destroy Troms of his own accord.

[1/1] Bak'al: Defend yourself. He is too far gone to control. You will be attacked.

[1/1] Bak'al: The Corrupter is awake. And he is close. Move, peon! You still must break the seal.
[1/1] Bak'al: I am unfamiliar with Twain magic. Use the intellect I have given you. Break the seal.
[1/1] Bak'al: Your job is done... And you survived. I will save you for another mission, should I need you. Now...watch.

[2/5] Scientist Urelix: Now, to business. Times are tough, as you know, and our Iron Golems are in high demand. However, we've, ah...
[3/5] Scientist Urelix: ...experienced a drought of ""volunteers."" Your job is decently simple; just- *ahem* convince some people to join the cause.
[4/5] Scientist Urelix: Three people should be enough for the moment. Look around the swamp for some folks, and lure them over here.
[5/5] Scientist Urelix: I'll stay in here and take care of them when you bring me them. It will absolutely be worth your while, I assure you.

[6/10] Antikythera Supercomputer: I CANNOT COMPUTE ANY OTHER POSSIBLE INTERPRETATION OF MY ORDER TO DESTROY THE HIGHEST THREATS AT THIS POINT.

[1/7] Legendary Attendant: Mo'in! Are you here to claim your rewards from the Legendary Challenge? Allow me to explain how the reward system works here.
[2/7] Legendary Attendant: As you probably already know, there are four tiers of tokens. Similarly, there are four merchants to match those.
[3/7] Legendary Attendant: You can purchase a base accessory at the Bronze Merchant.
[4/7] Legendary Attendant: Then, at the Silver Merchant, you can upgrade your Bronze accessory into one of six types of Silver accessories.
[5/7] Legendary Attendant: The six types are based on the five elements, along with another type that combines all five.
[6/7] Legendary Attendant: The Gold Merchant allows you to upgrade a Silver accessory into a Gold accessory of the same element.
[7/7] Legendary Attendant: The Diamond Merchant functions similarly. Thank you for participating in the Legendary Challenge!
[1/9] Legendary Attendant: Mo'in, and welcome to Legendary Island, home of the Legendary Challenge!
[2/9] Legendary Attendant: The Legendary Challenge consists of 10 powerful enemies, mostly based on some familiar faces.
[3/9] Legendary Attendant: The Challenge is divided into four tiers: Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Diamond.
[4/9] Legendary Attendant: The first 3 tiers have three challengers each, while the last, Diamond, has the final challenger.
[5/9] Legendary Attendant: Between each fight, you'll have the option to forfeit to claim a reward, or continue to risk a greater reward.
[6/9] Legendary Attendant: Someone will let you know what rewards you'll receive before you forfeit.
[7/9] Legendary Attendant: If you fail during a fight, you'll receive no reward at all and will have to try again from the beginning.
[8/9] Legendary Attendant: Between fights you'll be able to restock on resources if necessary.
[9/9] Legendary Attendant: Good luck!
[1/6] Dr. Legendary: Mo'in, traveler, and welcome to... LEGENDARY ISLAND! The ultimate test of strength!
[2/6] Dr. Legendary: With funding from the future province of Corkus, I went on a journey to study the strongest fighters in the world!
[3/6] Dr. Legendary: This means that here, at Legendary Island, you can fight my creations, recreations of the most powerful beings of all time!
[4/6] Dr. Legendary: There are 10 challengers for you to fight, and many prizes to collect!
[5/6] Dr. Legendary: The first challenger you'll face is based off of a Mummy that I discovered hidden in the desert: The Mummyboard!
[6/6] Dr. Legendary: You can challenge it now if you want, you can buy an entry ticket to the right.
[1/1] The Mummyboard: OS Version M-37 is now online. Systems estimate a 96.286573628% chance of success.
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Impressive work against the Mummyboard, but that was only the first challenger! Things have only just begun!
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: During my expedition across the world, funded by the amazing future province of Corkus, I happened upon a story about a doctor in Olux.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: Using samples of his so-called medicine, and stories about him, I managed to recreate the Plague Doctor as...
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: the Virus Doctor!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: You can continue and fight him now, or forfeit to your right, though you won't get much of a reward. The choice is yours.
[1/1] Virus Doctor: Ah! It seems I have a subject for my next experiment. Don't worry, human, this will only hurt... a lot.
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Seems you were able to best the Virus Doctor, but this is still the Bronze tier, so don't get too cocky!
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: After reading about a rare Gavel species with the properties of transformation, I knew I had to research it.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: Thanks to funding from Corkus, I managed to find it, the Corpus Accipientis, and created a golem with similar abilities.
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: I call it the Corkus Accipientis! This will be the final battle of the Bronze tier!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: You can continue and challenge it now, or you can forfeit to your right for a small reward. It's up to you!
[1/1] Corkus Accipientis: Scans indicate that your form is incredibly powerful. I will take it from you!
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Congratulations on defeating the Corkus Accipientis and completing the Bronze tier! If you win the next fight, you can start getting Silver tokens.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: My expedition, which was sponsored by Corkus, by the way, eventually lead me to the jungles of Wynn, where I heard rumors of an ancient idol.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: Though its name is rather hard to pronounce, I eventually managed to find and study the Matryoshka Idol.
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: And now you can fight one of my most resilient creations, the Matrojan Idol!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: You can give it a shot now, or forfeit for a reward to your right, as usual.
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: What a breathtaking fight! The Matrojan Idol, defeated! You're almost halfway there.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: During my travels, made possible by Corkus, I eventually stumbled into the Light Forest of Gavel, where I had a strange vision...
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: I saw... a villager, in his ultimate form, surrounded by mushrooms. The vision inspired me to create the next challenger.
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: I call this robot... YahyaBot V4.04!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: As always, you can forfeit to your right, or you can continue up ahead!
[1/2] Dr. Legendary: Good grief, what is that thing?! And... YahyaBot! Wrecked! This is a disaster! Oh dear, what am I to do now...

[2/2] Dr. Legendary: Oh- Traveler! It seems we've had a slight change in plans! Though this challenger is in pieces, if you can defeat this beast, I'll count it as a victory! Quickly, before it causes any more damage!
[1/6] Dr. Legendary: What a breathtaking fight! You've done it again! The Matrojan Idol, defeated! You're almost halfway there.
[2/6] Dr. Legendary: Now. Ahem. As you will remember, this next challenger was intended as YahyaBot V4.04.
[3/6] Dr. Legendary: But after your encounter with that beast last time, I got to thinking! What good is a fight without proper stakes? Wherein a single blow decides the match?!
[4/6] Dr. Legendary: No, no, such a fight will not do for Legendary Island! As such, I have decided to scrap the previous inhabitant of middle Silver, and have replaced it with...
[5/6] Dr. Legendary: The Titanium R.A.T. R-4X! All fixed up and ready for a rematch!
[6/6] Dr. Legendary: As always, if once was enough, you can forfeit to your right! Otherwise, continue up ahead!
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: My word, that was certainly unexpected! A shame YahyaBot was destroyed, and yet... What a fight that was! Astounding.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: ...Ahem. Anyways, during my Corkus-sponsored expedition, I eventually found and scaled the legendary Tower of Ascension.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: Up there, I met a peculiar creature, dressed up as the spirit of Death itself! Despite being an impostor, its strength was still formidable.
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: So the final fight of the Silver tier will be... Death Metal!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: As I'm legally obligated to remind you, you can forfeit to your right if you want.
[1/1] Dr. Legendary: Ladies and gentlemen, performing you live from Legendary Stadium... it's Death Metal and the Ascendant Bosses!
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Just as before, an astounding victory against the Titanium R.A.T. R-4X! We'll, ah, have to sort out damages to the arena later.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: Anyways, during my Corkus-sponsored expedition, I eventually found and scaled the legendary Tower of Ascension.
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Drat! And those mechs were so expe- Oh! Great job defeating Death Metal!
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: But this next one might be the end of you. The jungles of Wynn also spoke of a creature far more powerful and dangerous than the Idol.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: While I was unable to approach it myself, a man outside of a temple told me all about the monster in question.
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: Which is why I am proud to present you the Mechorrupter of Worlds, the first enemy of the Gold Tier!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: The reward for forfeit, to your right, isn't too bad. You can stop now if you want, or risk it all and keep going!
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Congratulations! You've defeated your first challenger of the Gold tier! That's more than most can say.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: But you're bound to have heard of the next challenger. During my Corkus-funded travels, I heard every story of Bob known to man.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: I amassed all of my research into one of my finest creations! So I wish you good luck in defeating the one and only...
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: Robob's Reinvention!
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: While I applaud you for getting this far, there's never any shame in forfeitting off to the side. But the choice is still yours.
[1/1] Robob: Only the most powerful warriors are worthy to face me. And by the looks of it, you barely made the cut.
[1/5] Dr. Legendary: Astounding! Very few have ever slain Robob. But this next challenger is known to very few, and still remains undefeated.
[2/5] Dr. Legendary: You've likely heard of Wybels. Have you heard stories of an orange one? They say an orange wybel is very intelligent and powerful.
[3/5] Dr. Legendary: I was unable to match its strength with electromagic alone, so I took a live Orange Wybel and... "upgraded" it into...
[4/5] Dr. Legendary: The Orange Cybel, the final challenger of the Gold tier. If you defeat it, you'll even be able to challenge the Diamond tier.
[5/5] Dr. Legendary: If you truly believe in your strength, continue. If not, I'd advise you to forfeit now. Your reward is already sizable.
[1/1] Orange Cybel: You've wasted every chance you had to turn back. And you're really not going to like what happens now.
[1/8] Dr. Legendary: Amazing! You even defeated the Cybel, my strongest creation. Well, except for one thing...
[2/8] Dr. Legendary: With the help of Corkus, I travelled to the Hive, where I sought to model the final challenger after the legendary sorceress.
[3/8] Dr. Legendary: But... Qira declined. She said that if I tried anyway, she'd, erm... well, let's just say killing me was putting it too lightly.
[4/8] Dr. Legendary: It might be for the best, anyways. If the stories about her are true, her immense skill might be impossible to replicate.
[5/8] Dr. Legendary: So instead, I made something else, something entirely new...
[6/8] Dr. Legendary: A mech suit that will be piloted by me, Doctor Legendary! With it, I might be one of the toughest foes you'll ever face!
[7/8] Dr. Legendary: But if you can defeat me, you'll get 1 Diamond Token, 7 Gold Tokens, 15 Silver Tokens, and 25 Bronze Tokens!
[8/8] Dr. Legendary: It's not too late to forfeit, if you want. But I have a feeling you've got one more fight in you.
[1/2] Dr. Legendary: So, you decided to come, then? Then let's see how you fare against the Champion of Legendary Island...
[2/2] Dr. Legendary: Doctor Herbert von Legendary!
[2/6] Dr. Legendary: I'm still in shock. I, the creator and controller of the strongest mechs in the world, have been defeated!
[3/6] Dr. Legendary: All of my research, sponsored by Corkus, of course, was still not enough. You have truly bested me.
[4/6] Dr. Legendary: I trust that you have received all of your tokens. You can make yourself a powerful accessory with all of those.
[5/6] Dr. Legendary: You've earned those tokens, but they might not be enough to maximize the power of an accessory.
[6/6] Dr. Legendary: You'll have to go through the challenge all over again if you want more tokens. And I'm ready for a rematch any time!

[1/5] Llevigar Archivist: Ahem. Here to return a book, are you? Let me see that.
[2/5] Llevigar Archivist: Wealth or Knowledge... Yes, I remember this book. Sixteen years overdue.
[3/5] Llevigar Archivist: Well, seeing as you certainly aren't the fellow who borrowed it, I suppose I won't fine you for it. Where did you find this, anyway?
[4/5] Llevigar Archivist: ...A dragon in the clouds? Certainly sounds like somewhere he would go. Well, regardless, welcome to Llevigar's Library!
[5/5] Llevigar Archivist: If you need me for anything, I'll be around. Otherwise, feel free to peruse our literature.
[1/1] Llevigar Archivist: Hm... Yes, hello. Do you need anything?
[1/2] Llevigar Archivist: Well, I suppose I'm something of an expert on history. You likely wouldn't find someone more knowledgeable than me... Unless they lived through it, of course!
[2/2] Llevigar Archivist: Ah, that aside. Is there a region you're particularly interested in?

[1/5] Llevigar Archivist: Wynn... Yes, yes, of course. You know, the humans in Wynn have never held history in as high regard as us Gavellians. As such, most of the information we have is... shall I say, incomplete.
[2/5] Llevigar Archivist: You humans instead choose to focus more on the present, rather than the past. That thousand-year war of yours has kept your people uniquely invested in the now.

[3/5] Llevigar Archivist: And, well... I think that's quite an admirable quality of your people. That you have survived a millenia of constant onslaught from the Corruption, and you still have hope for the present. For the future.

[4/5] Llevigar Archivist: So much of what we know of your history is directly tied to your war - from the event that started it all, to the modern politics of your cities. The Corruption is a constant all throughout, in a way that's unique to your province.
[5/5] Llevigar Archivist: And so, despite my interest in the history of the rest of the world, it is Wynn alone that fascinates me in this way.
[1/7] Llevigar Archivist: Gavel... Let's see here. I suppose a rather interesting period in our history which is relatively unknown is the time after Remikas' rule... And the Wars of the Cousins.

[2/7] Llevigar Archivist: After the death of Gavel's first king, the province saw a time of relative peace. His eldest daughter, Marika the Admired, had a long and peaceful rule until her passing in 463 BP.
[3/7] Llevigar Archivist: The crown was thus given to her son, Emil I. However, following the assassination of an advisor in his court, his legitimacy as king came into question.

[4/7] Llevigar Archivist: His two cousins, Alhard and Sivelle, claimed that Emil I was unfit to rule. Being children of Remikas' eldest son, Aramis, they believed they had a claim to the throne themselves.

[5/7] Llevigar Archivist: Alhard rebelled first, and later his children followed in his footsteps. The kingdom was split, with Alhard and Sivelle presiding in Kander Forest, and Emil I holding the citadel of Cinfras.

[6/7] Llevigar Archivist: Over the following decades, these civil wars would continue. Many times would these two factions come into conflict over who truly deserved the crown, prolonging the split of the monarchy.

[7/7] Llevigar Archivist: Eventually, in 431 BP, this conflict would finally come to an end. Sivelle's daughter, Raemin, took the crown, and finalized her victory by having her enemies beheaded. And thus, this period of history came to a close.
[1/1] Llevigar Archivist: Very well. I'll return to my work.
[1/4] Llevigar Archivist: Oh. I'll have to think on that question for a moment.
[2/4] Llevigar Archivist: ...Don't tell anyone this, but one of my favorites is a book titled 'The Long-Winded and Painful Death of Sweeney S. Greenville.'
[3/4] Llevigar Archivist: It is, as the title states, rather long... But it keeps a good sense of humor throughout. And humor is something I don't often find with this job of mine.
[4/4] Llevigar Archivist: I've worked here for nearly fourty years, myself. It's quiet work, but that's something I take solace in.
[1/4] Llevigar Archivist: Oh, don't get me started. He was a nice enough fellow, I suppose. Didn't cause many problems while he was here.
[2/4] Llevigar Archivist: He seemed interested in a variety of topics, and he read through many books while he frequented our library.
[3/4] Llevigar Archivist: I'm unsure he ever found what he was looking for, though. We have history, yes, but what he was looking for was more... exotic.
[4/4] Llevigar Archivist: Then, of course, he took one of our books and never returned it. For that, he has lost my respect.
[1/3] Llevigar Archivist: Oh! Chapter five, is it? Yes, it's certainly an oddity in comparison to the rest of the set.
[2/3] Llevigar Archivist: As for the reasoning for its removal... It's forbidden knowledge, you see. Ever since that Decay has taken hold, well...
[3/3] Llevigar Archivist: Let's just say our government does not look kindly upon talk of dark magic, and leave it at that.
[1/1] Llevigar Archivist: Well, hello then, fellow library-goer. If you don't mind, I'll get back to work now.

[4/12] ???: But I, Prince of the Avos, led the rest of my people down here, where no human could disturb us. And so, we lived here... for a while.
[5/12] ???: But avians like us are not suited to living underground. We became ill and lost our feathers. And eventually, my people died out.
[6/12] ???: Their souls still wander and cry throughout the ruins of my city.
[7/12] ???: However, I have remained here, still alive, hearing the plight and torment of the lost souls. For I am cursed to never die, only to be reborn.
[8/12] Phoenix Prince: Because of this endless cycle of reincarnation, I am only known as the Phoenix Prince.
[9/12] Phoenix Prince: After the death of all my people, your kind sealed the city, they likely didnt want anyone to know about what happened down here.
[10/12] Phoenix Prince: But unbeknownst to them, I was still here. Trapped forever, without even the escape of death. And it is all the fault of the humans who drove us here.
[11/12] Phoenix Prince: You're an invader, just like the rest of your people. They do not deserve to live on this island... on our island.
[12/12] Phoenix Prince: Prepare for our revenge. Prepare to DIE!

[1/8] Farcor: Ah... So another has sought me out. What is it you seek, human? Wealth? Power?
[2/8] Farcor: I am afraid you will be sorely disappointed... I will offer you neither.
[3/8] Farcor: If you have found your way here, you must know my story. I left Gavel a millennium ago...
[4/8] Farcor: Your people were not to blame for what befell this land. None of those who yet remain below can take the whole blame, truly... But still, they all had their part to play.
[5/8] Farcor: I have seen the Doguns fall, have watched as that Decay has twisted the land below. I remember, too, what those elves had done, all those years ago...
[6/8] Farcor: You are not the first to visit me, nor, I suspect, will you be the last. And when you leave, I will humbly await the next.
[7/8] Farcor: I regret that you came all this way for no reward... Perhaps I will gift you this book. It reminds me of days long past, before all this tragedy came to pass...
[8/8] Farcor: Now, human, leave me to rest. I have lived a long life, and I am very weary...
[1/2] Farcor: Hm... You are still here? Not many have stayed after hearing what I have to say. None, but one...
[2/2] Farcor: Have you come to seek my wisdom, then? What is it you have come for?
[1/9] Farcor: The Ahms region... It was my home and domain, once. Before those fools refused to listen to my warnings.

[2/9] Farcor: And a great land it once was. Similar to the Canyon which still lies to the west, yes, yet... Simpler. Greater. The walls did not shift, for their Protector had not yet encountered a threat it could not handle.
[3/9] Farcor: I roamed the land and gave my wisdom to any who would ask. They grew wiser, and they grew more powerful, all with my assistance...
[4/9] Farcor: Truly, I should have seen the signs long before the Fracturing. They were growing arrogant, and thought that they knew better than me.
[5/9] Farcor: And so, even as I warned them of incoming calamity, they chose to embrace their Protector. Not of their creation, no... But it was theirs nonetheless.
[6/9] Farcor: And as their Protector failed them, and fractured their land into pieces... They fell back on me. They sought my wisdom once more. They did not deserve it. So I left.
[7/9] Farcor: ...I suppose it is unfair to claim they all deserved that calamity. One section of the region, inhabited by folk unlike the others... They heeded my warnings. They prepared.
[8/9] Farcor: I do not know what came of them, after the Fracturing. Perhaps they, too, fell into the deep Void below. And yet... They prepared. They listened.
[9/9] Farcor: Hm. My apologies, I have been rambling on for far too long. I thank you for indulging this old man and his stories.
[1/3] Farcor: You would wish to restore this land...? Hm... No. No, I do not believe this can be done. It has been lost for far too long...
[2/3] Farcor: Ah, but that does not mean things cannot improve. You know this full well, yes? The war of the Heights has come to an end, and the Great Protector has been calmed...
[3/3] Farcor: I am glad this world is improving... Though I only wish such change could have come about sooner.
[1/3] Farcor: Hm... I have not descended into that dangerous abyss, for I fear the beings from between would not take well to my presence.
[2/3] Farcor: From what I can discern, it feels... strange. It is not of our realm, nor is it of the three which clash eternal. It is distinctly other.
[3/3] Farcor: I would urge you to stay alert if you choose to explore that place. Danger lurks in the unknown.
[1/4] Farcor: Ah... Yes. He came seeking my wisdom, many years ago. Though he did not plan to stay long, his visit soon became an extended stay.
[2/4] Farcor: It is... A light in my memory of millennia. We spoke of much, while he stayed here. He had theories and observations, and he sought my wisdom to confirm them.
[3/4] Farcor: I am unsure what came of him. His plans, as he spoke of them, would take him directly into danger. As he departed, he promised he would return if he succeeded.

[4/4] Farcor: ...As you would imagine, I have not seen him since. I worry for his safety, but I trusted his capabilities. I remain hopeful that, someday, he will come to me with good tidings. Until then, I will wait.
[1/4] Talking Mushroom: HEY! I HAVE A QUESTION, ACTUALLY!! SINCE YOU'RE SO WISE, COULD YOU TELL ME WHERE I WENT WRONG IN MY LIFE TO END UP IN THIS IDIOT'S POCKET?!
[2/4] Farcor: Ah... But of course. I have seen your journey, little mushroom. You have traveled quite a long way, have you not? Far from where you once called home...
[3/4] Farcor: You remind me of myself, in a way. A home left behind in a fit of anger, with no way to make amends.
[4/4] Farcor: Keep moving forward, little one. Someday, you will be at peace with your mistakes.
[1/1] Farcor: ...I see. I thank you for your kindness, human. It seems to be a rarity, these days...
